title: 107_hr3631
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wider Incentives for Non-Gasoline Small Electric Vehicles Act of 2002" or the "WINGS EV Act of 2002." It modifies the credit for qualified electric vehicles. The "Wider Incentives for Non-Gasoline Small Electric Vehicles Act of 2002" or the "WINGS EV Act of 2002" amends the credit for qualified electric vehicles by removing the 10 percent limitation and setting a maximum credit amount based on vehicle type and safety standards. The "WINGS EV Act of 2002" updates the credit for qualified electric vehicles by setting maximum credit amounts based on vehicle type and safety standards. For eligible 3-wheeled vehicles, the credit is the lesser of 10% of the manufacturer's suggested retail price or $4,000. For vehicles under 8,500 pounds, the credit is $4,000 or $6,000 if the vehicle has a driving range of at least 100 miles on a single charge. The "WINGS EV Act of 2002" updates the credit for qualified electric vehicles based on vehicle type and safety standards. For vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating exceeding 8,500 pounds, the credit amounts are set at $10,000, $20,000, and $40,000 based on weight categories. The "WINGS EV Act of 2002" updates the credit for qualified electric vehicles based on vehicle type and safety standards. Section 30 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to define a qualified battery electric vehicle as one operated solely by a battery or powered primarily through an electric battery using a flywheel or capacitor. The "WINGS EV Act of 2002" updates the credit for qualified electric vehicles based on vehicle type and safety standards. Section 30 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include eligible 3-wheeled vehicles as qualified battery electric vehicles, as long as they meet motor vehicle safety standards for motorcycles. The "WINGS EV Act of 2002" updates the credit for qualified electric vehicles. Section 30 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include eligible 3-wheeled vehicles as qualified battery electric vehicles, meeting safety standards for motorcycles. Amendments include driving range requirements and adjustments for leased vehicles. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include "Battery" after "Qualified" in various sections and headings. Section 30(d) is updated with additional special rules under the "WINGS EV Act of 2002" for qualified electric vehicles, including 3-wheeled vehicles meeting safety standards for motorcycles. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include rules regarding deductions and credits for costs related to determining credits. It also addresses the treatment of credits for vehicles acquired by tax-exempt entities, where the seller or lessor is allowed the credit if disclosed in the sale or lease contract. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the termination date to 2007. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2001, in taxable years ending after that date.
